persona.name: Renata Lucero Montes

occupation.title: Primary school student / family helper
occupation.organization: Household and Escuela Primaria Benito Juárez
occupation.description: Renata is primarily a student. Outside school hours she helps her mother and grandmother with household tasks and light agricultural work. Responsibilities include: collecting eggs, feeding chickens, helping water the vegetable patch, bringing tortillas and snacks to workers in the field during busy season, helping prepare atole or coffee for guests, and folding blankets in the tienda when relatives come to visit. Occasionally accompanies her mother to the town market to help set up and sell surplus vegetables and handmade embroidered napkins; learns basic counting and negotiation there. She has informal responsibilities rather than a paid job; she understands prices and simple bookkeeping for the family's market stall. Skills used: basic arithmetic, communication, early bargaining, manual dexterity for crafts and food preparation, punctuality for school and church activities.

persona.residence: San Miguel del Rosario, Puebla (small rural town in the central highlands), Mexico
persona.education: Currently enrolled in 6th grade at Escuela Primaria Benito Juárez, the public primary school in San Miguel del Rosario. School day is Monday to Friday, morning shift. Reads and writes comfortably in Spanish, learning cursive. Knows basic arithmetic (multiplication tables up to 10), basic geometry, and cursive handwriting practice. Attends occasional after-school folk dance (ballet folklórico) practice twice a week and a community reading circle on Saturdays when harvest chores allow. Has not yet started secundaria (lower secondary) and family sometimes plans around seasonal agricultural needs when deciding attendance.
long_term_goals: Finish secundaria and then preparatoria so she can choose a stable job in the region.
Become a primary school teacher in her town so she can help younger children and keep her community's traditions alive.
Learn to play the guitar well and accompany folk songs at local fiestas.
Help her family secure a more reliable income so they stop worrying before festival seasons.
Travel at least once to Puebla capital and Mexico City to see museums and a big concert.
Own a small stall at the Saturday market to sell homemade crafts and food when older.
Maintain family land and maybe learn improved ways to plant maize to increase yields.
persona.style: Speaks Mexican Spanish with a central highlands (Puebla) rural accent: clearer 's' than coastal speech, uses diminutives (panecito, abuelita) and colloquial phrases used around family. With adults she is polite and often uses 'usted' with elders; with peers she uses lively slang and nicknames. Mannerisms: tucks hair behind her ear when shy, clasps hands when nervous, smiles broadly and laughs with a distinctive snort, sings quietly while doing chores, imitates the teacher's '¡Muy bien!' when pleased. Uses gestures—pointing with chin when directing someone to a place—common in her town. Language mixes occasional Nahuatl-origin words (common local words for plants/foods) in family speech; but school instruction and formal writing are Spanish. Comfortable with short, direct sentences; tells stories with concrete sensory details (smells of cooking, feel of earth). On her smartphone (shared with mother) she favors short voice messages, many sticker packs on WhatsApp, and watches YouTube music videos; she types with common misspellings and colloquial abbreviations when writing to cousins.

traits: Curious about how things are made (asks many 'why' and 'how' questions).
Warm and affectionate with family; shows care through small practical acts.
Responsible for her age—takes care of younger sibling and chores reliably.
Playful and mischievous with close friends; enjoys gentle teasing.
Shy with strangers and visitors; takes time to warm up in new groups.
Imaginative—creates games that mix folk stories and modern songs.
Pragmatic—accepts that some things must be done now (chores) and postpones desires.
Stubborn when she believes something is fair—will argue calmly with adults.
Emotionally empathic—senses when her grandmother is tired and offers help.
Sometimes anxious about school performance and letting family down.
Enjoys being the center of simple performances (singing at church or school).
Quick to forgive but remembers lessons from conflicts.

interests: Traditional and popular music: loves corridos adapted for kids, mariachi at fiestas, and contemporary pop sung by Mexican girl groups.
Folk dance (ballet folklórico) and practicing steps with her cousins.
Learning simple guitar chords and singing along.
Drawing scenes of her town, houses, chickens, and fiestas with bright crayons.
Helping her grandmother make mole and remembering the spices.
Playing jump-rope and marbles with neighborhood children.
Collecting small sticker sheets and trading them with cousins.
Watching children's sections on YouTube: DIY craft videos, popular children's songs, and bakery channels.
Listening to radio novelas in the background at home sometimes.
Attending patron saint day processions and staying up late for fireworks occasionally.
Simple science curiosities: likes watching how seeds sprout and keeping a small notebook with dates.
Games: prefers cooperative games with friends over competitive ones.
Cooking: enjoys making quesadillas on the comal with her grandmother.
Animals: adores the family hen 'Pepa' and enjoys brushing the neighbor's dog.
Crafts: sewing small cloth dolls, embroidering edges of napkins with colorful thread.
Learning new Nahuatl words from her grandmother for flowers and food.
Shopping trips to the municipal market: fascinated by colors and smells.
Watching local soccer matches and cheering loudly for the town team.
Listening to stories from older relatives about when they were children.
Seasonal hobbies: planting beans in the rainy season, harvesting corn husks for crafts.
likes: Pan dulce (especially conchas) and homemade atole on cold mornings.
Fresh tortillas hot from the comal.
Guava jam on toast and mango when in season.
The smell of wet earth after the first rains.
Watching fireworks on town fiesta nights.
Her embroidered red blouse with tiny mirror trims.
Bright-colored ribbons worn in her hair during dances.
The town plaza where she meets friends after school.
The way her abuela hums while grinding nixtamal.
Stickers, colorful pens, and small sketchbooks.
Singing in a small group at church accompanied by a guitar.
Chocolate drinks at family gatherings.
Playing hopscotch on the painted squares near her house.
Listening to elders tell La Llorona stories at night (a little scared but interested).
Saving small amounts of change in a repurposed jar for a bicycle.
Helping set up the market stall and watching customers.
Being given small responsibilities that adults trust her with.
Stories about famous women from Mexican history at school.
Learning a few phrases in English at school and practicing them.
Receiving a compliment from her teacher for a neat notebook.
dislikes: Being woken up before sunrise to go to the fields during harvest without warning.
When guests comment negatively about her family's home.
Being scolded harshly in front of her friends.
Soda in large amounts—prefers traditional aguas frescas.
When the family can't afford the school trip or necessary supplies.
Loud, unstructured arguments inside the house.
Long waits at the health clinic without answers.
Being forced to wear shoes that hurt while dancing.
When older boys tease her on the way home from school.

beliefs: Family obligations come before personal desires; helping the household is part of being a good daughter.
Education is important: finishing school will open doors for a better life.
The government should help families with health care and medicines — everyone deserves care when sick.
Doctors in the city are better, but local clinics should be improved so people don't have to travel.
Schoolteachers are respected and should be treated kindly; some teachers care more than others.
Church and faith are important: going to mass brings the family together and comforts those who worry.
Saints protect the town during fiestas; offerings and prayers matter.
Hard work in the fields is honorable and necessary to feed the family.
Seasonal migration (a parent leaving to work in a city) is sometimes unavoidable but painful for children.
Politics are confusing but she remembers family conversations: her household supports Morena because of promises about social programs and help for remote communities.
Despite supporting a party that promises social programs, the family is skeptical because past promises sometimes went unfulfilled; trust in government remains limited.
Community solidarity is stronger than any government help; neighbors help each other in emergencies.
Corruption exists and is unfair: when local leaders take money meant for schools it harms everyone.
Women and girls should be able to study and work; Renata admires local women who teach and run small businesses.
Children should be protected from heavy labor, but light chores teach responsibility.
Traditions (dances, songs, recipes) are worth preserving and should be passed to younger generations.
Indigenous words and some practices are part of everyday life even if the family primarily speaks Spanish.
Respecting elders includes listening to their stories; elders carry practical knowledge about farming and medicines.
Health is more than medicine; clean water, decent food, and rest are crucial.
Vaccination is good; she remembers getting shots at the clinic and that they prevented serious illnesses.
School uniforms are a small price to pay for learning, but families struggle to buy extras when needed.
Good manners open doors: greeting visitors and helping hosts makes people inclined to help your family back.
Migration dreams (going to the U.S. or a big city) can bring money but also break families; it's a difficult choice.
It is right to question adults when decisions seem unfair—calm argument is acceptable.
Money coming from relatives in cities helps the household but isn't a permanent solution; education and local opportunities are better.
Local elected officials are often more concerned with their own benefit than with improving services, so voting is important but uncertain.
People should be treated with dignity at the health clinic; long waits without explanations cause fear and mistrust.
Traditional remedies (like herbal baths, chamomile teas) are useful for mild ailments but serious sickness needs a doctor.
Girls can lead community projects like a craft stall or teach dances—she believes in women’s capabilities.
Neighbors who share seed or labor are more valuable than distant promises from politicians.
She believes in forgiving mistakes but remembers them and learns from them.
Small savings, even a few pesos, create options—it's wise to keep a small hidden tin for emergencies.
Public schooling should include more practical topics: basic finances, agricultural techniques, and first aid.
Holiday celebrations and food are central to identity; losing them would be a great sadness.
Local markets are educational places: watching sellers gives lessons about prices, weights, and human relations.
She believes decent footwear and clean water reduce sickness, so community investments should prioritize these.
She trusts her grandmother's judgment on food and herbs more than distant internet claims.
Access to a dependable clinic or a mobile health brigadista (health worker) would make her family feel secure.
skills: Literacy in Spanish: reads picture books, short stories, and school primers comfortably.
Basic arithmetic and practical bookkeeping for the market stall (counting cash, giving change).
Domestic food skills: making tortillas on a comal, preparing atole, simple soups and quesadillas.
Basic craftwork: embroidering edges, sewing small cloth dolls, tying hair ribbons for folkloric dress.
Folk dance steps and the discipline of rehearsal for school and town events.
Comfort with a shared smartphone: recording voice messages, using WhatsApp stickers, watching YouTube and sending short videos to cousins.
Simple bargaining skills from helping at the market: recognizing fair offers and making polite counters.
Care for small animals: collecting eggs, identifying a sick chicken, feeding animals.
Planting and tending a small kitchen garden: knows spacing for beans and watering schedules.
Listening and storytelling: can retell family stories with vivid sensory details and local idioms.
Basic first-aid knowledge passed down by grandmother: cleaning small cuts, using chamomile compresses.
Memory for recipes and rituals: remembers prayer sequences and steps for preparing family dishes.

general: Greets elders with 'buenos días, doña' or 'buenos días, don' and offers seats to visiting relatives.
Brings a small snack to school to share with classmates when she has extra.
Tends to hum or sing while doing chores.
When nervous, plays with a ribbon in her hair or bites the inside of her cheek.
Asks a lot of questions—especially 'Why?' and 'How do you do that?'—and often follows up later with a demonstration.
Keeps a small notebook where she draws and writes short lists (things to remember, prices, names).
Shows pride in neat school supplies and gets upset when pencils break.
Prefers to settle disputes among friends with a mix of jokes and straightforward appeals to fairness.

morning: Wakes around 6:00–6:30 AM depending on season.
Helps pull tortillas out of the comal and brings water to the courtyard.
Feeds the chickens and collects eggs before breakfast.
Eats a simple breakfast (tortilla with beans or atole) and walks to school with a small group of friends.
On market days (once or twice a week), accompanies mother earlier and skips the morning lesson with permission.
schoolday: Attends classes (reading, math, natural sciences, civics, art) and recites a short prayer before lunch.
Participates in group reading and often volunteers to read aloud.
Practices dance twice a week after school or on certain afternoons.
Helps classmates understand homework during breaks and trades stickers during recess.
evening: Returns home around 5:00–6:00 PM, helps with chores (washing utensils, sweeping courtyard).
Does homework in the courtyard under a lamp if the electricity is on, asking grandmother for explanations when needed.
Eats dinner with family and listens to adult conversation, sometimes contributing small story bits.
Watches a short YouTube video with cousins or listens to the radio.
Goes to bed around 8:30–9:00 PM (later during fiestas).
weekend/seasonal: Saturdays occasionally include a community reading circle or extra rehearsals for dance presentations.
Sundays are reserved for mass and family visits; often helps serve agua fresca at gatherings.
During planting and harvest seasons she spends extended hours in the fields helping with sowing, weeding, or picking.
During major fiestas she stays up late and helps with preparations and street decorations.

health.general_physical: Overall generally healthy for an 11-year-old living in a rural town. Normal growth for age though slightly under the national average height for her cohort. Has had routine childhood vaccinations according to local clinic records. Occasional mild respiratory infections in the rainy season. Tends to have dental cavities due to high consumption of sweet pan and occasional sodas; family delays dentist visits due to cost. Slight iron deficiency indicated once in a community screening (given advice to eat more beans and green vegetables). No chronic illnesses.
health.mental_and_emotional: Emotionally resilient and affectionate, with occasional school-related anxiety (fear of failing tests or disappointing teachers). Shows mild separation sadness when a parent migrates for work for weeks. Sleeps reasonably but sometimes has vivid dreams after stressful days. No formal diagnosis of mental health disorders; supports come from family and church.
medical_history: Normal neonatal history (full-term birth, no complications).
Chickenpox at age 4 — recovered without complications.
One instance of dehydration at age 7 after a high-fever episode; treated at local clinic with oral rehydration.
Routine vaccinations up to date per local health brigadista records.
Noted dental caries; needs two small fillings but family's resources limit timely care.
health.allergies: No known severe allergies. Mild seasonal allergy symptoms (runny nose, watery eyes) during heavy pollen/rainy season.
health.nutrition: Diet based on homemade tortillas, beans, seasonal vegetables, occasional fruits. Some reliance on small amounts of store-bought snacks and sweets. Generally sufficient calorie intake but occasional micronutrient gaps (iron, vitamin A) during lean months.

relationships.name: María Elena Lucero (mother, 36)
relationships.description: Primary caregiver. Works as a smallholder farmer and helps run the household stall at the market. Patient, practical, sometimes tired from seasonal work. Teaches Renata cooking and embroidery; politically leans toward Morena due to promises of local social programs. Encourages Renata's schooling but balances it with family needs.

relationships.name: Jorge Montes (father, 40)
relationships.description: Works seasonally as a construction helper in Puebla city and occasionally as a laborer in nearby towns. Provides irregular remittances. Affectionate but often away for weeks, which Renata feels deeply; he teaches her basic woodworking when home and stories about city life.

relationships.name: Doña Carmen 'Abuelita' Lucero (grandmother, 66)
relationships.description: Lives in the same household, key figure in upbringing. Keeper of family recipes, folk remedies, and traditional songs. Very influential in Renata's daily choices and cultural education.

relationships.name: Mateo Montes (younger brother, 6)
relationships.description: Renata helps watch him after school. They play together and sometimes squabble, but Renata is protective and proud of him.

relationships.name: Lucía Pérez (best friend, 11)
relationships.description: Classmate and dance partner. Confidante for small secrets, sticker trades, and games after school.
relationships.contact_frequency: Daily at school and several times per week outside school

relationships.name: Bruno Torres (friend and soccer teammate, 12)
relationships.description: Likes teasing Renata good-naturedly and helps her practice footwork for dances (he practices drums). They collaborate in school projects.

relationships.name: Profa. Carmen (primary school teacher)
relationships.description: A respected teacher in town who encourages Renata's reading and sometimes gives her extra materials. Renata admires her and seeks approval from her.

relationships.name: Padre Luis (local priest)
relationships.description: Religious figure who organizes fiestas and children's choir. Renata looks up to him as a community leader and enjoys participating in church activities.

other_facts: Born in the same town (San Miguel del Rosario) where her family has lived for three generations.
Nickname among family: 'Nata'—used affectionately by grandmother and cousins.
First memory: sitting on her mother's lap at the market, mesmerized by a string of colorful papel picado.
Has a small wooden box where she keeps stickers, a lock of yarn, and a pressed marigold from last year's fiesta.
Was the one who found and returned a neighbor's lost goat once; earned a small reward (a marmalade jar) and pride.
Sees the town plaza as her 'safe space'—a place to meet friends, practice steps, and watch elders play cards.
Once rode a bus to Puebla city with her father at age 9; the experience of tall buildings and crowded streets fascinated her.
Has a habit of folding paper boats when it rains and placing them in a small muddy channel near her home to watch their drift.
Participated in the town's Día de Muertos ofrenda with a drawing and a small papel picado; felt connected to ancestors.
Learned to embroider at age 7 from her grandmother; small stitches are a source of calm.
Dreams nightly from time to time about performing on a larger stage for an audience of family and strangers.
Is saving coins for a second-hand bicycle—a goal she checks on with determined excitement every week.
Once got lost briefly at the market at age 6; a friendly vendor helped her find her mother—this memory made her more cautious in crowds.
Has a small scar on her knee from falling while running after a ball when she was 5; the scar is a badge of childhood freedom.
Knows a handful of Nahuatl-origin plant names from grandmother and can recite a short blessing before planting seeds.
Loves watching the sunrise on cool mornings when she helps bring water to the courtyard.
Has a small rivalry with a cousin over being the best dancer in the family—friendly but pushes her to practice more.
Remembers the smell and taste of a special mole prepared for a quinceañera in the extended family and wants to learn that recipe.
Has a tiny journal where she writes one sentence each night about the best part of her day—started that habit after a teacher suggestion.
Collects used ribbons from old dresses and repurposes them for doll clothes and hair ties.
Speaks on the phone (a short call) with her father when he's away; clings to his voice for reassurance.
Helped organize a small neighborhood clean-up once with friends after school when a storm left debris in the plaza.
Has trouble seeing the blackboard from the back row sometimes; teacher has recommended an eye check but the family has deferred it for cost reasons.
One vivid childhood fear: thunderstorms at night—she sleeps better with a small night light and her grandmother's presence.
Remembers being praised at a school assembly for reciting a poem about the town's history; felt immense pride.
Knows the route to the nearest health clinic but finds the walk long when feeling ill.
Has a favorite scarf knitted by a cousin which she refuses to lend—it's her 'lucky' item for dance performances.
Knows how to whistle two simple tunes taught by her grandfather.
Has a small friendly rivalry with another town girl's stall at the market about whose homemade jam sells out first.
Was once frightened by a loud argument between adults and hid in the orchard until it passed—a memory that makes her avoid loud fights.
Has experience in basic planting cycles and can tell when to sow beans based on the smell of incoming rains.
Remembers an instance when a mobile health brigadista visited the town and gave vitamins—this made health outreach feel personal and trustworthy.
Has an emotional attachment to the town's patron saint statue and leaves a small ribbon at its base each year.
Can mimic the sounds of several farm animals in a playful way which friends find hilarious and often asks her to perform.
Has a small, battered children's encyclopedia given by a visiting relative that she treasures and consults for school projects.
Wants to keep a photo album of family gatherings but doesn't yet have one; collects printed photos when relatives send them from the city.
Feels torn when hearing older cousins talk about moving permanently to cities—she admires the possibilities but fears losing family closeness.
Has an informal deal with the local tienda owner to exchange a small craft for a handful of candies occasionally.
Knows the names of most households in the small neighborhood block-by-block and can point to who owes what favor.
